content.title: Hawking Radiation: Black Hole Temperature and Evaporation
content.abstract: A worked example calculating the Hawking temperature, power, and evaporation time for black holes of various masses, demonstrating how Planck units naturally appear in quantum black hole physics.
content.problem_statement: Calculate the Hawking temperature, radiated power, and evaporation time for: (a) a solar-mass black hole, (b) an asteroid-mass black hole (10¹² kg), and (c) a Planck-mass black hole. What does this reveal about black hole thermodynamics?

step_1.title: Calculate Hawking Temperature
step_1.interpretation: Colder than the cosmic microwave background (2.7 K) by factor of 4×10⁷!

step_2.title: Calculate Schwarzschild Radius
step_2.interpretation: Solar-mass black hole has radius of only 3 km

step_3.title: Calculate Radiated Power
step_3.interpretation: Less than one photon per trillion years! Completely negligible.

step_4.title: Calculate Evaporation Time
step_4.interpretation: Far longer than current universe age (1.4×10¹⁰ years). Solar black holes are essentially eternal.

summary.conclusion: Astrophysical black holes gain mass from CMB faster than they evaporate

step_1.title: Calculate Hawking Temperature
step_1.interpretation: Hotter than the Sun's core (1.5×10⁷ K) by factor of 8000!

step_2.title: Calculate Schwarzschild Radius
step_2.interpretation: About the size of a proton!

step_3.title: Calculate Radiated Power
step_3.spectrum: Peak emission at X-ray energies (k_B T ≈ 10 MeV)

step_4.title: Calculate Evaporation Time
step_4.interpretation: Could have formed in early universe and be evaporating now

summary.conclusion: Primordial black holes of this mass would be detectable and evaporating today

step_1.title: Calculate Hawking Temperature
step_1.interpretation: Within an order of magnitude of Planck temperature!

step_2.title: Calculate Schwarzschild Radius
step_2.interpretation: Exactly 2 Planck lengths! The minimum possible black hole.

step_3.title: Calculate Radiated Power
step_3.interpretation: The Planck power! Total power of 10²⁶ Suns in one tiny point.

step_4.title: Calculate Evaporation Time
step_4.interpretation: One Planck time! Explodes essentially instantly.
step_4.energy_release: E = m_P c² ≈ 2 × 10⁹ J ≈ 500 kg TNT equivalent

summary.conclusion: Planck-mass black hole is the extreme case where quantum gravity fully dominates

temperature_scaling.implication: Small black holes are hot; large ones are cold

evaporation_scaling.interpretation: Lifetime scales as cube of mass

critical_mass.question: What mass black hole has T_H = CMB temperature (2.7 K)?
critical_mass.interpretation: Moon-mass black holes are in thermal equilibrium with CMB

primordial_black_holes.significance: Such primordial black holes would be exploding now
primordial_black_holes.observation: Gamma-ray bursts could be signatures; none conclusively identified

planck_scale_physics.observation: All Planck-mass black hole properties are Planck scale
planck_scale_physics.conclusion: Planck units are the natural scales for quantum black holes

key_results: Solar black hole: T = 6×10⁻⁸ K, τ = 10⁶⁷ years (eternal)
Asteroid-mass (10¹² kg): T = 10¹¹ K, τ = 3 billion years
Planck-mass: T ~ T_P, τ ~ t_P, r_s ~ ℓ_P (all Planck scale)

prerequisites.title: Planck Temperature Definition
prerequisites.reason: Hawking temperature is fraction of Planck temperature

related.relationship: Black hole entropy connects to holography

Carroll, S. (2004): Spacetime and Geometry, Ch. 6: Black Holes

validation.notes: Hawking temperature formula and evaporation calculations validated against Hawking's original paper and standard textbooks.

learning_objectives: Calculate Hawking temperature for black holes of various masses
Derive evaporation timescales using mass-lifetime relation
Understand why Planck-mass black holes are extreme cases
common_errors: Forgetting 8π factor in Hawking temperature formula
Confusing lifetime scaling (∝M³) with temperature scaling (∝1/M)
Not recognizing that stellar black holes never evaporate
